review.title: Scalable Deep Traffic Flow Neural Networks for Urban Traffic Congestion Prediction
review.abstract: Tracking congestion throughout the network road is a critical component of Intelligent transportation network management systems. Understanding how the traffic flows and short-term prediction of congestion occurrence due to rush-hour or incidents can be beneficial to such systems to effectively manage and direct the traffic to the most appropriate detours. Many of the current traffic flow prediction systems are designed by utilizing a central processing component where the prediction is carried out through aggregation of the information gathered from all measuring stations. However, centralized systems are not scalable and fail provide real-time feedback to the system whereas in a decentralized scheme, each node is responsible to predict its own short-term congestion based on the local current measurements in neighboring nodes.

sections.heading: II. PRELIMINARIES
sections.text: In this section, we give formal definitions of the problem of predicting traffic flows in section II-A. Then, in section II-B, we formally present the problem presented in this paper.

sections.heading: A. Formal Definitions
sections.text: A traffic network comprises a series of roads, as well as a series of nodes, each designated by N. → Nodes can be intersections of roads, exits of motorways, roundabouts, beginning-end points of a road, U-bends, etc. Nodes can be considered the most important points of the network, as these points can be important factors for changing traffic flows. To explain this, a traffic flow typically does not have to change significantly between two nodes, but it can change due to traffic lights, exit and so on. Consequently, almost all points of the traffic network and traffic sensors can be installed in the nodes. Definition 1 (Network points): In this study, we represent a road (roads, motorways, etc.) based on the nodes on that road. Each of these points can indicate the traffic condition (for example congestion).

sections.heading: B. Problem Definition
sections.text: Suppose we have the historical network snapshots of a region (e.g. Northern California) obtained by traffic detectors at traffic points (definition 1). Our system can learn traffic patterns from these historical data. Suppose we have the current and current network snapshots of another region (e.g. Southern California), as the latter was recently equipped with traffic sensors. In this thesis, we try to predict traffic flows in the latter region based on traffic patterns we learned from the former traffic network. Problem. Given the historical traffic observations of Network N1 and Snapshot (S, now), we predict traffic status from S (now + 1), where (now + 1) is the next time (e.g. traffic status in 20 minutes).

sections.heading: III. DEEP TRAFFIC FLOW NETWORK
sections.text: In this section, we will try to solve the problem defined in Section II-B with two deep learning models, using two prominent algorithms, namely Convolutional Neural Network [8] in Section III-A and Long Short-Term Memory [6] in Section III-B.

sections.heading: IV. EXPERIMENTAL EVALUATION
sections.text: In order to examine the performance of our model, we will explain our models in detail, followed by the presentation of our data set. In section IV-A we will describe our data set, and in section IV-B we will explain our method in more detail.

sections.heading: B. Deep learning-based method
sections.text: Now that we have the normalized cleaned data from subsection IV-A, we need to implement two deeper methods in section III, namely Deep Traffic Flow convolutional Network and Long-term memory Traffic Flow, to successfully avoid the traffic flow (traffic patterns) of a specific road network, N1. Then, the learned models should be used to predict another road network, N2, (see subsection II-B.) In this experiment, we use the first 20 network points of the normalized cleaned data as a training set and the remaining 30 network points as a test set. As we know, the earlier network points are southern dataset, and the latter belong to the northern section. The two sets are disjoint to evaluate the generalizability of the proposed methods (see subsection II-B).To evaluate the proposed methods, we employed a system as follows: • Intel (R) Core (TM) i7 CPU 960 @ 3.20GHZ 8GB

sections.heading: V. CONCLUSION
sections.text: Concepts of traffic bottlenecks and congestion are critical components of intelligent traffic network management systems. Great efforts have been made to understand how traffic flows and the short-term prediction of the occurrence of congestion due to peak times or incidents, such as car accidents or sporting events, can be useful for such systems to effectively control traffic and direct it to the most appropriate detours. Most traffic flow forecasting systems rely on the use of a central processing component, where the prediction is made by aggregating the information collected from all measurement stations. However, such systems are typically scalable and unable to provide real-time feedback to the system, while in a decentralized scheme each node is responsible for predicting its own short-term congestion of current local measurements in adjacent nodes. In this work, we introduced a scalable decentralized traffic forecast based on data flows, using a learning-based methodology developed from deep flows.

metadata.abstractText: Tracking congestion throughout the network road is a critical component of Intelligent transportation network management systems. Understanding how the traffic flows and short-term prediction of congestion occurrence due to rush-hour or incidents can be beneficial to such systems to effectively manage and direct the traffic to the most appropriate detours. Many of the current traffic flow prediction systems are designed by utilizing a central processing component where the prediction is carried out through aggregation of the information gathered from all measuring stations. However, centralized systems are not scalable and fail provide real-time feedback to the system whereas in a decentralized scheme, each node is responsible to predict its own short-term congestion based on the local current measurements in neighboring nodes. We propose a decentralized deep learning-based method where each node accurately predicts its own congestion state in realtime based on the congestion state of the neighboring stations. Moreover, historical data from the deployment site is not required, which makes the proposed method more suitable for newly installed stations. In order to achieve higher performance, we introduce a regularized euclidean loss function that favors high congestion samples over low congestion samples to avoid the impact of the unbalanced training dataset. A novel dataset for this purpose is designed based on the traffic data obtained from traffic control stations in northern California. Extensive experiments conducted on the designed benchmark reflect a successful congestion prediction.
